tag-1: Brazil: GVces and Citi Launch 2012 Stage of Program to Promote Innovation and Sustainability in the Value Chain
tag-3: São Paulo, Brazil – When the Sustainability Studies Center (GVces) at the Fundação Getúlio Vargas's São Paulo School of Business Administration (FGV-EAESP) launched its "Innovation and Sustainability in the Value Chain" program in December 2011 and announced its partnership with Citi through the sponsorship of the Citi Foundation, it presented three cases to illustrate the project's goals and potential for cooperation between small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and big corporations:
tag-4: 1) Ouro Verde Amazônia, an SME in Alta Floresta in the state of Mato Grosso, works with Grupo Orsa to explore the sustainable production of non-wood products from the Amazon through projects with local communities, 2) Terpenoil, based 60 kilometers from São Paulo in Jundiaí, supplies big companies such as Whirlpool with cleaning products for industrial processes made with the naturally occurring organic element terpene, and 3) Cotia-based Pack Less has developed a new type of moving pallet made without wood for companies such as Braskem.
tag-5: All three of these examples represent successful instances of cooperation between SMEs and large corporations to develop innovative and sustainable products, services and business models with the potential to improve processes, reduce costs and risks, and make more efficient use of resources.
tag-6: In 2012, Innovation and Sustainability in the Value Chain will focus on provider management. This phase of the project will feature three specialized workshops to promote contacts and knowledge sharing among SMEs and large corporations and present case studies. A team of GVces sustainability specialists will select cases submitted by SMEs to become part of a virtual platform offering a database of innovative projects. The six best cases, along with the three announced at the beginning of the project, will be profiled in a publication released in September at the Innovation and Sustainability in the Value Chain Forum to wrap up the project's 2012 stage.
tag-7: SMEs interested in participating in the selection process should submit their cases online at www.fgv.br/ces/inova. Large corporations can access the same site for information about how to join the project and participate in the 2012 workshops.
tag-8: Priscilla Cortezze, head of Corporate Affairs and Sustainability at Citi, points out that large corporations with operations in Brazil are subject to increasingly strict sustainability standards. "Adapting to these standards is a challenge, but also an opportunity for innovation," she notes. "The increased international demand for Brazilian products also means that our companies have to meet the highest social and environmental standards, and a failure to innovate could result in a loss of competitiveness."
tag-9: According to GVces Program Coordinator Paulo Branco, Innovation and Sustainability in the Value Chain will have a positive long-term impact on Brazilian society in general. "We are changing the linear cycle of 'get it-use it-throw it out' to a 'borrow-use-return' mode of production that is sustainable and takes into account the planet's limits."
tag-10: GVces The Sustainability Study Center (GVces) was created in 2003 out of the pressing need for companies, their financers, stockholders, leaders, insurers, consultants and auditors to understand, measure and evaluate the risks and opportunities associated with non-financial impact areas such as the environment, corporate social responsibility and corporate governance. Its mission is to contribute to implementing sustainable development in many different areas - equity, social justice, ecological balance and economic efficiency - through the study and dissemination of concepts and practices.
tag-11: FGV-EAESP Founded in 1954, the São Paulo School of Business Administration at the Fundação Getulio Vargas (FGV-EAESP) was Latin America's first business school and has a long tradition of training leaders in the areas of business, government and academia. Known as one of the most prestigious academic centers for the study of business and public administration, the school is characterized by its constant development of research and pioneering studies and is at the forefront of applied knowledge, which it disseminates through publications and projects at its various research centers. Several of its programs have been listed recently in national and international rankings. FGV-EAESP is ranked as the Best School of Business in Brazil, with top grades from the Ministry of Education. It is the first institution in Latin America and one of only a few in the world to obtain triple international accreditation for the quality of its instruction from the AACSB, EFMD and AMBA.
tag-12: The Citi Foundation The Citi Foundation is committed to the economic empowerment and financial inclusion of individuals and families, particularly those in need, in the communities where we work so that they can improve their standard of living. Globally, the Citi Foundation targets its strategic giving to priority focus areas: Microfinance, Enterprise Development, Youth Education and Livelihoods, and Financial Capability and Asset Building. The Citi Foundation works with its partners in Microfinance and Enterprise Development to support environmental programs and innovations. Additional information can be found at www.citifoundation.com.
tag-13: Citi Citi, the leading global bank, has approximately 200 million customer accounts and does business in more than 160 countries and jurisdictions. Citi provides consumers, corporations, governments and institutions with a broad range of financial products and services, including consumer banking and credit, corporate and investment banking, securities brokerage, transaction services, and wealth management.
